title: 109_s575
content: The "Educational Opportunity for All Act of 2005" introduces the Educational Opportunity Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Educational Opportunity for All Act of 2005" introduces the Educational Opportunity Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified tuition expenses paid during the taxable year, with a maximum limit of $4,000 per individual. Taxpayers also have the option to elect not to apply this credit for a specific individual's expenses in a taxable year. The term "attendance" refers to the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent attending an eligible educational institution for courses. Exceptions include education involving sports, games, hobbies, and nonacademic fees like student activity and athletic fees. The term "eligible educational institution" refers to an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965, eligible for programs to acquire or improve job skills. The tax credit for qualified tuition expenses under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 has special rules, including the requirement to include the individual's name and taxpayer identification number on the tax return. Additionally, any amounts paid for the individual's benefit, such as qualified scholarships, will reduce the qualified tuition expenses for that academic period. The tax code allows for the exclusion of certain educational assistance allowances and payments for educational expenses from gross income. If a taxpayer claims a deduction for an individual's expenses, those expenses cannot be claimed by another taxpayer in the same year. The tax code prohibits double benefits by disallowing a credit if a deduction is claimed for the same expenses. Prepaid tuition expenses for an academic period starting within three months after the taxable year are considered paid in that year. The tax code prohibits double benefits by disallowing a credit if a deduction is claimed for the same expenses. Qualified tuition and related expenses for individuals claiming the Hope Scholarship Credit or Lifetime Learning Credit cannot be used for this credit. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for this credit, and nonresident aliens may also be ineligible. The tax code disallows double benefits by prohibiting a credit if a deduction is claimed for the same expenses. Nonresident aliens may be ineligible for certain credits, such as the Hope Scholarship Credit or Lifetime Learning Credit. Regulations may be prescribed for recapturing credits in cases of refunds in subsequent taxable years. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including inserting references to section 36 after section 25A. The table of sections is also updated to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section introduce an educational opportunity tax credit and address overpayments of tax. These changes will apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2004, for education provided in academic periods starting after that date.
